CommentsTitle: Stick Sensitivity is Drastically Below Standard
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 29, 2020
CommentsContent: tldr: Radial stick deadzones are 60% of the total movement. Unusable for FPS games.Informative version:Overall the controller gets a 1/5 rating based on the importance of the defect.The Good:95% of the controller is absolutely fine. It's super lightweight, so it feels good in your hands. The buttons aren't as smooth as on some controllers but they function just fine; no sticking or extra wobble from being too small. The rumble is nice and the cord length is ideal for PC use. Price point is great, and the controller looks and feels very similar to a Microsoft Xbox controller. Solid construction, no wobbly or loose parts.The Bad:The other 5% makes this controller unusable for almost any shooter games; the joysticks.I will preface by saying I've tested this on 5 different games and went through every setting from lowest to highest in terms of sensitivity, acceleration, and deadzone adjustments. The only thing I can't rule out is a defective controller, as I've only tested mine.The biggest flaw is these sticks have a HUGE deadzone. When moving the stick with the 4 directions, deadzone is normal. This is what i would expect from any controller. When checked 8 directions, the flaw becomes glaring. The 4 diagonals have a deadzone of 50%-60% of the allowed movement before they kick in. This makes any movement that is not 4 directional (which is 99% of modern shooters) essentially not possible. The joysticks are arguably the most crucial part of a controller and these do not make the cut. There is a certain level of quality expectation when buying off-brand equipment. It'll be 'Fine'. Not perfect, not great like an OEM version, but just fine and you can use it normally and have saved some money. This product does not make that cut. It falls below fine as it cannot function the way it NEEDS to function.If they were to correct this problem, I would say this would be a 10/10 product. As is, the 1 flaw is too essential to it's intended use to give this anymore than a 2/10.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 5, 2020
CommentsContent: I really wanted to love these controllers. My wife and I just ordered three to complement her one OEM controller without breaking the bank. And, for the money, they’re decent. Really, I only have one complaint, but it’s major enough that it warrants a 3-star rating. The only issue I’ve seen (aside from the slight physical quality loss that almost always comes with 3rd-party devices - which in this case is negligible) is that the thumbsticks have a significant delay. On any OEM controller for Xbox or PlayStation, any slight movement of the thumbsticks initiates some movement onscreen. However, these controllers do not have this. You have to move the stick by 1/4-1/2 a centimeter before it actually sends a signal to the console. This means that fine aiming adjustments onscreen cannot happen. Where an OEM controller essentially allows for a gradual “0-60 acceleration,” these go directly from 0 to 60, with no buildup. As someone who enjoys playing games well and really gets into them, this is maddening and can ruin one’s ability to make instant target acquisition a thing. To verify that this was a consistent issue with VOYEE, I tested all three of these controllers against our Microsoft controller on several CoD and Borderlands titles, with several sensitivity levels across each game, and VOYEE failed every time.Now, does this mean that the controller is useless? Not at all. Again, for the money, it’s decent. I plan to keep two as backups or for split-screen gaming. However, I personally would not be okay using this controller as my go-to for CoD, Halo, or any other fast-paced, competitive title. I can manage to work around the imprecise aiming, but I feel no need to do so when I can hunt down a used OEM device for a similar price, even if it will take a bit of bargain-hunting.

CommentsTitle: Don't buy this controller, the analog sticks function poorly.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 11, 2020
CommentsContent: This is a terrible controller for any first person shooter.  To exaggerate only a little, as you push further and further on the analog stick initially nothing happens, and then suddenly everything happens and your character on the screen goes from not moving to moving too fast, with not enough motion in between.  It makes me wonder if the variable resistors inside have an audio taper instead of a linear taper, but that is just speculation; I did not preform any measurements with a multimeter.  So, to exaggerate a little, it goes from nothing to everything instead of being more in control of the left or right stick's motions.  Aka, instead of being analog, the sticks act more digital than they should. However, all the buttons and the triggers work great. It's a cheap $16 controller clone of a Microsoft brand $40 controller, only the clone got a couple of crucial things wrong, namely the analog sticks.  There is also no electromagnetic shielding on the wires running from the controller to your system, which may or may not be the reason for an almost unnoticeable slowing down (when using graphics intense games) of the system as it tries to filter out the extra noise from the controller, but it is so unnoticeable it may not be fair to even mention it.  And there is no break away connector on that wire either, but it is not like I am going to let kids play on my system anyway, after all, games are not for kids ;).  (kidding). What I did find is that the controller works great with puzzle games, where analog motion on the sticks is not required so much, so I am not returning mine.  I just wish it would work much better with all my other games, than it does. Also don't buy the name brand "Voyee" controller for a couple of dollars more like I did thinking you will get a better controller than the no name brand controller for a few dollars less, because they are the same controller exactly, because if you look at the reviews, it show the same functionality and problem in both controllers, strange brand or no brand, there is no difference. CommentsContent: Updated Review September 25:So, I am a week or so late with this, but after posting the original review and also sending a message to the Voyee customer service, they replied back to me on the same day a few hours later, asking for my number and address for a replacement. I gave it to them, and they sent the replacement, which came the following week (original review was on a Friday), working perfectly! Seriously surprised at how fast it all was, and also that I even got a reply from customer service the same day! All praise and hail Voyee, exceeders of expectations! (Don't care if that word doesn't exist)Original 3 star review from September 11, 2020:So I got this controller back in May 29, 2020, and up until a couple weeks ago, it worked well. The left analog stick was a little too sensitive when moving the camera in games, but I didn't mind that, I saw that as training fine motor skills, somewhat.But my issue is that, randomly and for no reason, my controller is vibrating constantly, even when nothing is on. My TV and Xbox was turned off, but I walked into my room and the controller was vibrating. I unplugged the controller and it stopped, but plug it back in and it vibrates. I turned off vibration in the xbox, controller still vibrates. I unplugged the Xbox, it still vibrates. And, as a hunch, because the controller is USB, I plugged it into my TV which has a USB port, and the controller is vibrating. Other than the vibration, the controller works perfectly, but I dont know what will happen if this continues on, especially since I only got this thing just over 3 months ago.Basically, I love the controller, but I may have to get a new one because it won't stop vibrating.

CommentsContent: It's functional as a controller, but only just.~The stick inputs are very insensitive, making it difficult to adjust for intensity of directional input. This makes it feel like one is playing with a controller built of Legos in games that require tight controls, such as FPS's or tactical stealth-shooters. On the topic of poor stick inputs, the controller does not register small differences between specific directional input. For example, one can either go left, forward, or forward-left. There is no variation in-between the three directional movements, again making precision control impossible.~Buttons become sticky after basic use. No damage has occurred to the controller yet there are times when unpressed buttons continually send unintentional inputs.For anyone buying a replacement controller, spend the extra $10-$20 and shop elsewhere. This controller is only acceptable for use with basic Smart-TV video game apps. Any use with a half-way decent title will leave you with regret.
